titleText.ttltext: Global, regional, and national estimates of pneumonia morbidity and mortality in children younger than 5 years between 2000 and 2015: a systematic @hit_startanalysis@hit_end

organizations: Centre for Global Health Research, Usher Institute of Population Health Sciences and Informatics, University of Edinburgh

abstracts.publisherCopyright: © 2019 The Author(s). Published by Elsevier Ltd. This is an Open Access article under the CC BY 4.0 license
paras: Background: Global child mortality reduced substantially during the Millennium Development Goal period (2000–15). We aimed to estimate morbidity, mortality, and prevalence of risk factors for child pneumonia at the global, regional, and national level for developing countries for the Millennium Development Goal period. Methods: We estimated the incidence, number of hospital admissions, and in-hospital mortality due to all-cause clinical pneumonia in children younger than 5 years in developing countries at 5-year intervals during the Millennium Development Goal period (2000–15) using data from a @hit_startsystematic review@hit_end and Poisson regression. We estimated the incidence and number of cases of clinical pneumonia, and the pneumonia burden attributable to HIV for 132 developing countries using a risk-factor-based model that used Demographic and Health Survey data on prevalence of the various risk factors for child pneumonia. We also estimated pneumonia mortality in young children using data from multicause models based on vital registration and verbal autopsy. Findings: Globally, the number of episodes of clinical pneumonia in young children decreased by 22% from 178 million (95% uncertainty interval [UI] 110–289) in 2000 to 138 million (86–226) in 2015. In 2015, India, Nigeria, Indonesia, Pakistan, and China contributed to more than 54% of all global pneumonia cases, with 32% of the global burden from India alone. Between 2000 and 2015, the burden of clinical pneumonia attributable to HIV decreased by 45%. Between 2000 and 2015, global hospital admissions for child pneumonia increased by 2·9 times with a more rapid increase observed in the WHO South-East Asia Region than the African Region. Pneumonia deaths in this age group decreased from 1·7 million (95% UI 1·7–2·0) in 2000 to 0·9 million (0·8–1·1) in 2015. In 2015, 49% of global pneumonia deaths occurred in India, Nigeria, Pakistan, Democratic Republic of the Congo, and Ethiopia collectively. All key risk factors for child pneumonia (non-exclusive breastfeeding, crowding, malnutrition, indoor air pollution, incomplete @hit_startimmunisation@hit_end, and paediatric HIV), with the exception of low birthweight, decreased across all regions between 2000 and 2015. Interpretation: Globally, the incidence of child pneumonia decreased by 30% and mortality decreased by 51% during the Millennium Development Goal period. These reductions are consistent with the decrease in the prevalence of some of the key risk factors for pneumonia, increasing socioeconomic development and preventive interventions, improved access to care, and quality of care in hospitals. However, intersectoral action is required to improve socioeconomic conditions and increase coverage of interventions targeting risk factors for child pneumonia to accelerate decline in pneumonia mortality and achieve the Sustainable Development Goals for health by 2030. Funding: Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation.

titleText.ttltext: Prevalence of human papillomavirus DNA and p16@sup_beginINK4a@sup_end in penile cancer and penile intraepithelial neoplasia: a @hit_startsystematic review@hit_end and @hit_startmeta@hit_end@hit_start-analysis@hit_end

organizations: Unit of Virus, Lifestyle, and Genes, Danish Cancer Society Research Centre

paras: Background: Although previous @hit_startmeta@hit_end@hit_start-analyses@hit_end have examined human papillomavirus (HPV) DNA prevalence in penile cancer, none, to our knowledge, have assessed pooled HPV DNA prevalence in penile intraepithelial neoplasia or p16@sup_beginINK4a@sup_end percent positivity in penile cancer and penile intraepithelial neoplasia. Therefore, we aimed to examine the prevalence of HPV DNA and p16@sup_beginINK4a@sup_end positivity in penile cancer and penile intraepithelial neoplasia worldwide. Methods: In this @hit_startsystematic review@hit_end and @hit_startmeta@hit_end@hit_start-analysis@hit_end, we searched @hit_startPubMed@hit_end, @hit_startEmbase@hit_end, and the @hit_startCochrane@hit_end Library until July 24, 2017, for English-language articles published from Jan 1, 1986, onwards reporting the prevalence of HPV DNA and p16@sup_beginINK4a@sup_end positivity, either alone or in combination, in at least five cases of penile cancer or penile intraepithelial neoplasia. Only studies that used PCR or hybrid capture for the detection of HPV DNA and immunohistochemical staining or methylation for the detection of p16@sup_beginINK4a@sup_end were included. Data were extracted and subsequently crosschecked, and inconsistencies were discussed to reach consensus. Using random-effects models, we estimated the pooled prevalence and 95% CI of HPV DNA and p16@sup_beginINK4a@sup_end positivity in penile cancer and penile intraepithelial neoplasia, stratifying by histological subtype and HPV DNA or p16@sup_beginINK4a@sup_end detection method. Type-specific prevalence of HPV6, HPV11, HPV16, HPV18, HPV31, HPV33, and HPV45 in penile cancer was estimated. Findings: Our searches identified 1836 non-duplicate records, of which 73 relevant papers (71 studies) were found to be eligible. The pooled HPV DNA prevalence in penile cancer (52 studies; n=4199) was 50·8% (95% CI 44·8–56·7; I@sup_begin2@sup_end=92·6%, p@sub_beginheterogeneity@sub_end<0·0001). A high pooled HPV DNA prevalence was seen in basaloid squamous cell carcinomas (84·0%, 95% CI 71·0–93·6; I@sup_begin2@sup_end=48·0%, p@sub_beginheterogeneity@sub_end=0·0197) and in warty-basaloid carcinoma (75·7%, 70·1–81·0; I@sup_begin2@sup_end=0%, p@sub_beginheterogeneity@sub_end=0·52). The predominant oncogenic HPV type in penile cancer was HPV16 (68·3%, 95% CI 58·9–77·1), followed by HPV6 (8·1%, 4·0–13·7) and HPV18 (6·9%, 2·9–12·4). The pooled HPV DNA prevalence in penile intraepithelial neoplasia (19 studies; n=445) was 79·8% (95% CI 69·3–88·6; I@sup_begin2@sup_end=83·2%, p@sub_beginheterogeneity@sub_end<0·0001). The pooled p16@sup_beginINK4a@sup_end percent positivity in penile cancer (24 studies; n=2295) was 41·6% (95% CI 36·2–47·0; I@sup_begin2@sup_end=80·6%, p@sub_beginheterogeneity@sub_end<0·0001), with a high pooled p16@sup_beginINK4a@sup_end percent positivity in HPV-related squamous cell carcinoma (85·8%, 95% CI 72·1–95·4; I@sup_begin2@sup_end=56·4%, p@sub_beginheterogeneity@sub_end=0·0011) as compared with non-HPV-related squamous cell carcinoma (17·1%, 7·9–29·1; I@sup_begin2@sup_end=78·3%, p@sub_beginheterogeneity@sub_end<0·0001). Moreover, among HPV-positive cases of penile cancer, the p16@sup_beginINK4a@sup_end percent positivity was 79·6% (95% CI 65·7–90·7; I@sup_begin2@sup_end=89·9%, p@sub_beginheterogeneity@sub_end<0·0001), compared with 18·5% (9·6–29·6; I@sup_begin2@sup_end=89·3%, p@sub_beginheterogeneity@sub_end<0·0001) in HPV-negative penile cancers. The pooled p16@sup_beginINK4a@sup_end percent positivity in penile intraepithelial neoplasia (six studies; n=167) was 49·5% (95% CI 18·6–80·7). Interpretation: A large proportion of penile cancers and penile intraepithelial neoplasias are associated with infection with HPV DNA (predominantly HPV16), emphasising the possible benefits of HPV @hit_startvaccination@hit_end in men and boys. Funding: None.

titleText.ttltext: Does prior dengue virus exposure worsen clinical outcomes of Zika virus infection? A @hit_startsystematic review@hit_end, pooled @hit_startanalysis@hit_end and lessons learned

organizations: Viral Diseases Branch, Walter Reed Army Institute of Research

abstracts.publisherCopyright: © 2019, Public Library of Science. All rights reserved.
paras: Zika virus (ZIKV) recently caused a pandemic complicated by Guillain-Barre syndrome (GBS) and birth defects. ZIKV is structurally similar to the dengue viruses (DENV) and in vitro studies suggest antibody dependent enhancement occurs in ZIKV infections preceded by DENV; however, the clinical significance of this remains unclear. We undertook a PRISMA-adherent @hit_startsystematic review@hit_end of all current human and non-human primate (NHP) data to determine if prior infection with DENV, compared to DENV-naïve hosts, is associated with a greater risk of ZIKV clinical complications or greater ZIKV peak viremia in vivo. We identified 1146 studies in @hit_startMEDLINE@hit_end, @hit_startEMBASE@hit_end and the grey literature, of which five studies were eligible. One human study indicated no increase in the risk of GBS in ZIKV infections with prior DENV exposure. Two additional human studies showed a small increase in ZIKV viremia in those with prior DENV exposure; however, this was not statistically significant nor was it associated with an increase in clinical severity or adverse pregnancy outcomes. While no @hit_startmeta@hit_end@hit_start-analysis@hit_end was possible using human data, a pooled @hit_startanalysis@hit_end of the two NHP studies leveraging extended data provided only weak evidence of a 0.39 log10 GE/mL rise in ZIKV viremia in DENV experienced rhesus macaques compared to those with no DENV exposure (p = 0.22). Using a customized quality grading criteria, we further show that no existing published human studies have offered high quality measurement of both acute ZIKV and antecedent DENV infections. In conclusion, limited human and NHP studies indicate a small and non-statistically significant increase in ZIKV viremia in DENV-experienced versus DENV-naïve hosts; however, there is no evidence that even a possible small increase in ZIKV viremia would correlate with a change in ZIKV clinical phenotype. More data derived from larger sample sizes and improved sero-assays are needed to resolve this question, which has major relevance for clinical prognosis and @hit_startvaccine@hit_end design.

titleText.ttltext: CERVICAL CANCER AND HPV INFECTION AMONG INDIGENOUS WOMEN IN CANADA

abstracts.publisherCopyright: © 2019 The Society of Obstetricians and Gynaecologists of Canada
paras: Objectives: In this @hit_startliterature review@hit_end we aimed to determine whether cervical cancer screening and HPV @hit_startvaccination@hit_end measures implemented to date are acceptable and accessible to our Indigenous peoples. Methods: @hit_startPubMed@hit_end, Ovid, @hit_startMedline@hit_end, and Google Scholar were queried using the following search terms: [include search terms], resulting in 49 documents. All documents found were reviewed and 19 were found to be relevant and useful for this @hit_startliterature review@hit_end. The articles include @hit_startanalyses@hit_end of traditional cervical cytology (“Pap test”)screening program, patient reluctance about this screening technique, the prevalence of high-risk types of HPV infection and HPV @hit_startvaccination@hit_end uptake in Indigenous women population in Canada. Results: The results of this @hit_startliterature review@hit_end seem to indicate that the following factors do not seem to significantly influence the screening among Indigenous women in Canada: the under-detection by Pap test, the reluctance vis-à-vis the Pap test and the lack of education concerning HPV and cervical cancer. Also, it is now known that the current HPV @hit_startvaccination@hit_end program with Gardasil9 covered type-specific HPV infection found in Indigenous women. Unfortunately, results show that HPV @hit_startvaccination@hit_end rates are lower in Indigenous women than in non-Indigenous women even if current @hit_startvaccination@hit_end programs might be effectively protective. Conclusions: This @hit_startliterature review@hit_end, which is not a @hit_startsystematic literature review@hit_end, is a proof that the work isn't finished and that we are far from having found a solution to the high prevalence rate of HPV and cervical cancer among Indigenous women in Canada.

sourceTitle: Journal of Obstetrics and Gynaecology Canada

titleText.ttltext: Interventions to increase the distribution of @hit_startvaccines@hit_end in sub-saharan africa: A scoping review

organizations: Centre for the Development of Best Practices in Health, Yaoundé Central Hospital

paras: Achieving universal access to @hit_startimmunization@hit_end, as envisioned in the global @hit_startvaccine@hit_end action plan continues to be a challenge for many countries in Sub-Saharan Africa. Weak @hit_startimmunization@hit_end supply chain (iSC) has widely been recognized as a key barrier, hindering progress towards @hit_startvaccination@hit_end targets in this region. These iSCs, which were designed in the 1980s, have become increasing fragile and are now considered outdated. The objective of this review was to assess the effectiveness of system redesign and outsourcing to improve outdated iSC systems in sub-Saharan Africa. We searched the following electronic databases from January 2007 to December 2017: @hit_startMedline@hit_end, @hit_startEMBASE@hit_end (Excerpta Medica Database), the @hit_startCochrane@hit_end Library, Google Scholar, @hit_startCINAHL@hit_end (Cumulative Index to Nursing and Allied Health Literature), WHOLIS (World Health Organization Library Database), LILACS (Latin American and Caribbean Literature on Health Sciences) and contacted experts in the field. Our search strategy yielded 80 records and after assessment for eligibility, seven papers met the inclusion criteria. Five studies evaluated the experiences of system redesign in three countries (Nigeria, Benin and Mozambique), two assessed outsourcing @hit_startvaccine@hit_end logistics to the private sector in Nigeria and South Africa. According to these studies, system redesign improved @hit_startvaccine@hit_end availability at service delivery points and reduce the cost of distributing @hit_startvaccines@hit_end. Similarly, outsourcing @hit_startvaccine@hit_end logistics to the private sector reduced the cost of @hit_startvaccines@hit_end distribution and improve @hit_startvaccine@hit_end availability at service delivery points.

titleText.ttltext: Efficacy and safety of antigen-specific immunotherapy in the treatment of patients with non-small-cell lung cancer: A @hit_startsystematic review@hit_end and @hit_startmeta@hit_end@hit_start-analysis@hit_end

organizations: Cancer Center, The First Hospital of Jilin University

paras: Background and Objective: We performed this @hit_startsystematic review@hit_end and @hit_startmeta@hit_end@hit_start-analysis@hit_end to assess the efficacy and safety of antigen-specific immunotherapy (Belagenpumatucel-L, MAGE-A3, L-BLP25, and TG4010) in the treatment of patients with non-small-cell lung cancer (NSCLC). Methods: A comprehensive literature search on @hit_startPubMed@hit_end, @hit_startEmbase@hit_end, and Web of Science was conducted. Eligible studies were clinical trials of patients with NSCLC who received the antigen-specific immunotherapy. Pooled hazard ratios (HRs) with 95% confidence intervals (95%CIs) were calculated for overall survival (OS), progression-free survival (PFS). Pooled risk ratios (RRs) were calculated for overall response rate (ORR) and the incidence of adverse events. Results: In total, six randomized controlled trials (RCTs) with 4,806 patients were included. Pooled results showed that, antigen-specific immunotherapy did not significantly prolong OS (HR=0.92, 95%CI: 0.83, 1.01; P=0.087) and PFS (HR=0.93, 95%CI: 0.85, 1.01; P=0.088), but improved ORR (RR=1.72, 95%CI: 1.11, 2.68; P=0.016). Subgroup @hit_startanalysis@hit_end based on treatment agents showed that, tecemotide was associated with a significant improvement in OS (HR=0.85, 95%CI: 0.74, 0.99; P=0.03) and PFS (HR=0.70, 95%CI: 0.49, 0.99, P=0.044); TG4010 was associated with an improvement in PFS (HR=0.87, 95%CI: 0.75, 1.00, P=0.058). In addition, NSCLC patients who were treated with antigen-specific immunotherapy exhibited a significantly higher incidence of adverse events than those treated with other treatments (RR=1.11, 95%CI: 1.00, 1.24; P=0.046). Conclusion: Our study demonstrated the clinical survival benefits of tecemotide and TG4010 in the treatment of NSCLC. However, these evidence might be limited by potential biases. Therefore, further well-conducted, large-scale RCTs are needed to verify our findings.

titleText.ttltext: @hit_startSystematic review@hit_end of group a streptococcal emm types associated with acute post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis

organizations: Department of Microbiology and Immunology, Peter Doherty Institute for Infection and Immunity, University of Melbourne

abstracts.publisherCopyright: Copyright © 2019 by The American Society of Tropical Medicine and Hygiene.
paras: Acute post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis (APSGN) is a postinfectious immune-mediated kidney disease associated with group A Streptococcus (GAS). The prevalence of APSGN varies within and between countries and is influenced by socioeconomic, host, and bacterial factors. The disease is more prevalent in developing countries and resource-poor settings of developed countries, such as the Indigenous populations residing in tropical Australia. The M-protein is a universally present GAS surface antigen that is the focus of molecular typing and @hit_startvaccine@hit_end research. Early reports suggested that some M-proteins (emm types) are more likely to cause APSGN than others. Here, we present the first @hit_startsystematic review@hit_end of the global distribution of APSGN-associated GAS emm types. There were 46 emm types among the 676 cases described in 15 reviewed articles. Only 43% APSGN cases would have had theoretical coverage from the experimental M protein-based GAS @hit_startvaccine@hit_end. @hit_startVaccine@hit_end coverage was higher in regions such as North America (97%) and the United Kingdom (98%) than Africa (67%) and Australia (38%). Variable @hit_startvaccine@hit_end coverage against APSGN - associated emm types highlights the need for further research into this disease, particularly in settings of poverty, where APSGN prevalence is higher. Three GAS emm types (emm49, emm60, and emm55) consistently occur in APSGN cases around the world. Future studies would therefore benefit from examining the genomic epidemiology of these emm types to unravel potential markers of APSGN.

titleText.ttltext: How is communication of @hit_startvaccines@hit_end in traditional media: a @hit_startsystematic review@hit_end

organizations: Department of Journalism and Communication, University Carlos III of Madrid

paras: Aim: Taking into account that a key determinant in public approval of @hit_startvaccinations@hit_end is how the media constructs and frames messages about @hit_startvaccination@hit_end programmes, our aim is to review communication studies exploring media coverage of @hit_startvaccines@hit_end within traditional media venues. Methods: Using a registered protocol (PROSPERO: 42017072849), a @hit_startsystematic review@hit_end was conducted that searched in three international electronic databases (@hit_startPubMed@hit_end, Scopus, and the International Bibliography of Social Science) for articles published between 2007 and 2017 following content-@hit_startanalysis@hit_end methods. The characteristics and outcomes were systematically identified and described. The search yielded 24 eligible studies that were further @hit_startanalysed@hit_end in the review. Results: Media coverage of @hit_startvaccines@hit_end has been largely studied during the last decade. Findings revealed that 62% (n = 15) of studies @hit_startanalysed@hit_end the human papillomavirus @hit_startvaccine@hit_end, 87% (n = 21) examined newspapers, and 62% (n = 15) examined North American media. In relation to media content @hit_startanalyses@hit_end, 75% found negative messages on @hit_startvaccines@hit_end and 83% identified a lack of accurate information. Conclusions: This @hit_startsystematic review@hit_end suggests an agenda for further research. There is a significant need to @hit_startanalyse@hit_end other types of traditional media beyond newspapers. Future studies should focus on other geographical areas such as low-income countries and on @hit_startanalysing@hit_end visual materials and digital media. We found that negative messages and inaccurate information are common in media coverage on @hit_startvaccines@hit_end; therefore, further research focusing on these topics is needed. Officials in public health organizations should develop a close collaboration with the media to improve public communication on @hit_startvaccines@hit_end.

titleText.ttltext: The effect of influenza @hit_startvaccination@hit_end on mortality and hospitalization in patients with heart failure: a @hit_startsystematic review@hit_end and @hit_startmeta@hit_end@hit_start-analysis@hit_end

organizations: Core Laboratory, Nagoya City University Graduate School of Medical Sciences

abstracts.publisherCopyright: © 2018, Springer Science+Business Media, LLC, part of Springer Nature.
paras: Influenza infection is associated with increased risk for mortality and hospitalization in heart failure patients. Although there are no published randomized controlled trials examining the effect of influenza @hit_startvaccination@hit_end on clinical outcomes in heart failure patients, the effect has been examined in observational cohort studies. Nevertheless, results are inconsistent due partly to limited power with small sample sizes and use of different definitions of outcomes. We therefore aimed to conduct a @hit_startsystematic review@hit_end and @hit_startmeta@hit_end@hit_start-analysis@hit_end of the effect of influenza @hit_startvaccination@hit_end on mortality and hospitalization in heart failure patients. The search of electronic databases identified 6 observational cohort studies with 22,486 patients examining the effect of influenza @hit_startvaccination@hit_end on mortality and hospitalization in heart failure patients. Pooled @hit_startanalysis@hit_end of confounder-adjusted hazard ratio showed that influenza @hit_startvaccination@hit_end was associated with reduced risk of mortality during 1-year follow-up (risk ratio [95% CI] = 0.76 [0.63–0.92], P@sub_beginfix@sub_end < 0.01) and during long-term (up to 4 years) follow-up (0.80 [0.71–0.90], P@sub_beginfix@sub_end < 0.001). Furthermore, influenza @hit_startvaccination@hit_end was associated with reduced risk of mortality during influenza season (risk ratio [95% CI] = 0.52 [0.39–0.69], P@sub_beginrandom@sub_end < 0.001) and during non-influenza season (0.79 [0.69–0.90], P@sub_beginfix@sub_end < 0.001). Only a few studies reported the effect of influenza @hit_startvaccination@hit_end on hospitalization, which did not permit us to perform pooled @hit_startanalysis@hit_end. In conclusion, our @hit_startmeta@hit_end@hit_start-analysis@hit_end showed that influenza @hit_startvaccination@hit_end was associated with reduced risk of mortality in heart failure patients. Large-scale and adequately powered randomized controlled trials should be planned to confirm our observed potential survival benefit of influenza @hit_startvaccination@hit_end in these patients.

titleText.ttltext: Rotavirus infections in children in Turkey: A @hit_startsystematic review@hit_end

organizations: Department of Pediatric Infectious Diseases, Gazi University Faculty of Medicine

paras: We aimed to describe rotavirus epidemiology and clinical findings including extraintestinal manifestations in a setting that has yet to introduce rotavirus @hit_startvaccines@hit_end in the national @hit_startimmunization@hit_end program. A literature search was performed by using the key words “Turkey” and “rotavirus.” Ninety-eight studies published between 1987 and 2016 including epidemiological, clinical, and genotypical data at least 1 year duration were included. There were a total of 117 741 children with diarrhea and 26 566 rotavirus gastroenteritis with a median detection rate 31.8% (95% CI, 31.3-32.4) under 5 years of age. The rate of dehydration was 47% (95% CI, 23.4-91.6). There were 328 cases reported to be presenting with a various complication related to rotavirus in 2750 children in eight studies. The overall complication rate was 11.7% (95% CI, 10.7-12.9). The cumulative incidence of the most common genotypical combinations circulating worldwide was only 59.7% (G9[P8], 25%; G1[P8], 22%; G2[P4], 5.6%; G3[P8], 2.6%; G4[P8], 4.5%) whereas mixed, untypeable, and other genotypes were 2.4%, 15%, and 22.9% respectively. Our results point out the importance of rotavirus @hit_startvaccination@hit_end by presenting that rotavirus may cause severe complications besides severe gastroenteritis. The role of strain diversity in the variability of clinical presentations of rotavirus infections needs to be further investigated.
